awd_titl_txt: Scholarships in STEM To Achieve Results (S-STAR)
awd_abstract_narration:
Through the Scholarships in STEM To Achieve Results (S-STAR) project, East Los Angeles College (ELAC) will provide scholarship support for 15-20 students annually.  The awards will be available on a competitive basis to all science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors who demonstrate finanical need and the aptitude to succeed in STEM disciplines.  Data shows that attrition in STEM disciplines is disproportionately high among Hispanic students at ELAC.  Building on the infrastructure established by the institution's Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement (MESA) and Academic and Student Support to Improve Student Transfer (ASSIST) programs, S-STAR will provide not only scholarships, but also supplemental instruction, access to a STEM Study Center, one-on-one counseling, mentoring, research and internship opportunities, professional development workshops, and other support services that are strategically planned to foster student success.  Being the state's largest Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), ELAC is implementing S-STAR to increase the number of academically talented, underrepresented STEM students successfully prepared for transfer to four-year STEM degree programs, and ultimately to high-skill, high-wage jobs in fields of local and national need.  Additionally, this project will contribute to diversity in research.  By increasing S-STAR students' competitiveness and encouraging them to participate in undergraduate research, these students will more likely to attend graduate school.

S-STAR objectives are to: (1) alleviate economic burdens of college students with demonstrated financial need, while improving students' educational opportunities; (2) increase retention, success rates and degree completion; and (3) increase the number of skilled STEM students ready to succeed in technical areas of local and national need by increasing their competitiveness to participate in research and internship experiences within four-year institutions, industry, and/or national labs, while at the community college.  Both qualitative and quantitative data collection efforts will be used to assess the attainment of the objectives.  Ongoing dissemination of incremental outcomes, best practices and lessons learned is planned through scholarly articles focused on women and minorities in science and engineering, community college STEM student success, and through presentations at conferences that offer platforms to share knowledge among both community colleges and four-year institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The strongest and most consistent outcomes were found for short- and long-term persistence favoring student who participated in the program activities: peer mentoring, STEM cohort, summer academy, supplemental instruction (SI) in math, SI in science, technology and engineering (STE), STEM counseling, tutoring, academic coaching and research internships. For each of the two models (any one or more program activities, any two or more program activities), significant differences were found, favoring students over their matched non-program counterparts, controlling for the 9 covariates in the regression models. For short-term persistence (two consecutive semesters), the average higher odds of persisting ranged from 2.5 to 4.8 for those who participated in program compared to their matched counterparts. In the case of longer-term persistence (three consecutive semesters), the average higher odds of persisting ranged from 1.7 to 2.5 for those who participated in program compared to their matched counterparts. The magnitude of these persistence results is considerable and establishes the key role that program academic support activities played in persistence.

Strong outcomes were also found for increases in cumulative units, again favoring program students over matched comparison students. Results indicated that cumulative units in the last semester enrolled ranged from 9.3 to 11 units higher, on average, among students who participated in program activities compared to their matched counterparts and controlling for units in first semester enrolled and the 9 covariates in the regression models. Increasing cumulative units also represents successful course retention and course completion. Therefore, a clear positive relationship between program academic support activities and completing more classes was found based on the persistence and cumulative units results. In other words, better retention was achieved by program students compared to their matched counterparts. Higher retention, in turn, is a key step towards successful transfer and degree completion.

Results for increases in GPA were more modest and nuanced. Students who participated in two or more program activities had an average of a 0.13 higher GPA than their matched counterparts, controlling for first semester GPA and the 9 covariates in the regression model. An interaction effect provided more nuanced results for students who participated in any one or more program activities. In this model, students with lower first semester GPAs made greater GPA gains from program activities compared to their matched counterparts, ranging from 0.12 (for first GPA of 3.0) to 0.32 (for first GPA of 0.0) mean GPA differences favoring program students, while no differences were found among program and non-program students with a first GPA of 4.0. Thus, mean grade differences were more difficult to achieve and were at a smaller magnitude than cumulative units and persistence results, with greater benefits found for program students with lower first GPAs.

Analysis of the 9 program activities individually indicated that some academic support activities on their own may be better suited to contributing to persistence rather than increases in GPA or cumulative units. This was the case based on the non-significant cumulative units and GPA analyses for Peer Mentoring, STEM Cohort, and Summer Academy, and to a lesser extent for Academic Coaching in which a significant cumulative unit interaction indicated greater gains were made by those with higher first semester units (more experienced college students), but no differences were found in GPA. Other academic support activities on their own contributed to increases in both cumulative units and GPA, as well as persistence. This was the case based on the significant cumulative units, GPA, and persistence results for SI Math, SI STE, STEM Counseling, and Tutoring, and to a lesser extent, SI STEM Cohort (which had significant cumulative units and persistence results but non-significant GPA results).

In summary, program academic support activities individually and when provided together appear to be making a difference in academic outcomes for Latinx and low-income STEM students at ELAC. Positive outcomes for program students included higher odds of persistence ranging from 1.7 to 4.5 for consecutive two and three semesters, substantive increases in cumulative units ranging from a mean of 9.3 to 11 units earned, and modestly higher GPAs of .13 for those who participated in two or more program activities, and for those who participated in one or more program activities, higher GPAs were a function of lower first semester GPAs.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2022
Modified by: Djuradj Babic
